text:
Marleny, your data does not need to match the data structure of the API. The API data is totally different!
The data from your form just needs to be saved in the backend, in a repo. The simplest place to put it would be in the beer repo. You don't need to save all of the data from the form--the act of answering silly questions and filling it out is what will make the app fun! but we don't need to keep a record of every single answer--but you may end up adding a field or two to the existing beer model class, beer repo and beer dto if you'd like. Ryan's fridge will just pull "ID" "Beer Name", "ABV", "Tasting Notes". The actual beer repo can have other fields that we don't display in the fridge.

elements.text:
Marleny, your data does not need to match the data structure of the API. The API data is totally different!
The data from your form just needs to be saved in the backend, in a repo. The simplest place to put it would be in the beer repo. You don't need to save all of the data from the form--the act of answering silly questions and filling it out is what will make the app fun! but we don't need to keep a record of every single answer--but you may end up adding a field or two to the existing beer model class, beer repo and beer dto if you'd like. Ryan's fridge will just pull "ID" "Beer Name", "ABV", "Tasting Notes". The actual beer repo can have other fields that we don't display in the fridge.

text: This way, you can work with the existing data structures, adding to them as you see fit, and ultimately save yourself the trouble of coding from the ground up.

text: I am sorry to learn of the confusion! The API data, classes, dto, et al have to do with the data from the third party API. The third party API is an entirely separate component from our backend Beer repo. Data from the third party API is hosted on the third party API server; it is not hosted in any of our backend repos. The data from your form submission is to be used to create a new record in our backend Beer repository. The data the user submits in the front end form would be transferred to the backend by means of beer dto. The data from the third party API is handled (transferred from the third party API to the backend) using an API dto.

elements.text: I am sorry to learn of the confusion! The API data, classes, dto, et al have to do with the data from the third party API. The data from your form submission is to be used to create a new record in our backend Beer repository. The data the user submits in the front end form would be transferred to the backend by means of beer dto. The data from the third party API is handled (transferred from the third party API to the backend) using an API dto.

text:
Your features do not involve third party API calls, so they don't need to cohere to the fields in any dto or model class labeled "API".
In order for your features to integrate with the rest of the app, ie, Ryan's features and my features, you need to send the response data to the backend to be stored in the beer repository, as we discussed. To send data from the front end to the beer repository, you'll need to cohere to the structure of the beer dto and model class. This is why we mentioned that you could add fields to both as you see fit--it wouldnt mess up Ryan's work and it would allow for a bit more data to be stored.

text:
Hi Marleny, I'm afraid I don't really understand the issue, but I am sorry if there's been any miscommunication. The good news is that Ryan's features, Suburwa's features and my features are all integrated smoothly, so we are really close to the finish!

I had understood that you were on the same page as everyone else and I'm really sorry if there are some lingering spots of confusion. 

The front end that you made before the new year did not work on anyone's computer other than your own. This is why we collectively agreed to move forward with a new front end about 17-20 days ago. If I recall correctly, Alex was also present at that meeting.

As for the trouble now, I'm happy to help you however I can.

Specifically "when i asked if my data object had to match your fields..." to which fields are you referring?

text:
Hi Marleny, I am sorry to see that you feel that way! 
After we collectively agreed on our features and developed an approximate idea of how they'd connect, I was under the impression that we were all working under our own direction. 
As a group project with individual components, we were each to be responsible for guiding our own features and adapting them to fit one another in the spirit of collaboration. No one was providing us with exact or precise instructions or guidelines. This is both the challenge and the beauty of collective work without an established hierarchy or manual. Suburwa, Ryan and I each worked on our own stuff and reached out when we had a question. While I am sorry for the lingering miscommunication, I think it's pretty unfair to say that someone else is responsible for proactively checking on your own features. 
Please keep in mind that the last time we got together to merge to main and share code, your backend still was not running. This means that we had no glimpse into your code, as you had into ours. 
The good news is that as programmers, we can all look at simple code and get a pretty decent idea of what is going on with the app! This has allowed us all to work together and build off of each other's features. More often than not, the answers one seeks can be found in the code.
That all to say:
-If you look at Ryan's fridge, you'll see what repo the beers come from. That's the repo that you'll need to send the newly created beers to. 
-If you look at my features, which I've recently described in the chat, you'll see that the recommended beers list searches using ABV (as you and I had previously discussed) and also "one taste word". Honestly, this doesn't even have to integrate with your feature. It's fine as a standalone for now. If you want, you could have a word of flavor field in the form. NBD at this point in time.
-The beer name generator works by accessing and updating the most recently created beer: that with the biggest ID number. I've already sent a screen shot and description.

Honestly, this doesn't even have to integrate with your feature. It's fine as a standalone for now. If you want, you could have a word of flavor field in the form. NBD at this point in time.
-The beer name generator works by accessing and updating the most recently created beer: that with the biggest ID number. I've already sent a screen shot and description.
